thread.title: Sunderland Central constituency General Election 2017 - candidates and the history of the seat

author: Mike Kelly
title: Sunderland Central constituency General Election 2017 - candidates and the history of the seat

organizations.name: school of health and social care

text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
If you’re due to cast your vote in the Sunderland Central constituency on June 8 we’ve got everything you need to know right here. 
Britain will go to the polls to elect a government and prime minister after Theresa May called a snap general election. 
We’ll be covering events on our live blog on election day , but in the meantime we’ve got the information you need before you decide which box to put your cross in. 
Which parties and candidates are standing in Sunderland Central ? Labour - Julie Elliott Julie Elliott 
Julie grew up with her parents and older brother and sister in Whitburn. 
She attended Whitburn Infant School, Whitburn Junior School and Seaham Northlea Comprehensive, later gaining a degree in Government and Public Policy at Newcastle Polytechnic – now known as Northumbria University. 
She is a mother-of-four and served as a school governor for Whitburn Comprehensive from 1991-2004, including a stint as chair. She also served as a governor at primary schools across Sunderland and South Tyneside . 
Outside of her parliamentary duties, Elliott enjoys spending time with her children and grandchildren, walking the coastline of her constituency and watching International Rugby Union. Green - Rachel Featherstone 
Rachel has lived in Sunderland all of her life. 
She has worked in shops, a factory, a market stall, and two of the city’s call centres. 
Rachel has attended the University of Sunderland , and then Durham University, as a mature student after the birth of her daughter. 
She works as a senior lecturer in Research Methods in the School of Health and Social Care at Teesside University and is an active trade unionist, currently serving as my branch Equality Officer, and sitting on the regional committee and Women Members’ Standing Committee. 
When not working, Rachel enjoy cups of tea, cakes and the company of her teenage daughter. Lib Dem - Niall Hodson 
Niall grew up in Sunderland and lives in the city centre with his wife. 
He was elected to Sunderland Council in May 2016 and as a councillor has campaigned to save vital services like libraries, lollipop men and women, regular street cleaning and bin collections. 
Niall trained as an art historian and has worked with museums and galleries across the North East, as well as teaching at a local university and overseas. 
He believes strongly in opening museums and cultural venues up to wider audiences, and gives regular art history tours for a local charity. Conservative - Robert Oliver 
Robert was born in Sunderland in 1972 and lives at the Lakeside Village in St Chad’s ward which he represents on Sunderland City Council. 
He is a teacher and works full-time, teaching mainly sixth form classes in politics and also history to younger pupils. 
As well as running the school’s Debating Society and Law Club he organises a biennial visit to the Battlefields of Ypres and the Somme. 
When away from work he likes to spend some of the school holidays travelling, especially to Spanish-speaking countries as he speaks the language. In recent years he has worked for the youth development charity Raleigh International on a local government project in Chilean Patagonia and often takes a short trip to Spain. 
Sport is also a favourite pastime especially swimming at a local club, running and cycling. Also running but with no information yet... 
Gary Leighton - UKIP What was the result in Sunderland Central in 2015? 
Julie Elliott (Lab): 20,959 (50.2%) 
Jeff Townsend (Con): 9,780 (23.4%) 
Bryan Foster (UKIP): 7,997 (19.1%) 
Rachel Featherstone (Green): 1,706 (4.1%) 
Adrian Page (Lib Dem): 1,105 (2.6%) 
Joseph Young (Ind): 215 (0.5%) 
Turnout: 57.0% 
Winner: Julie Elliott (majority 11,179) Which parties and MPs have held the seat in the past? 
All Sunderland seats have been Labour since the 1960s, however there are pockets of Tory support in more affluent areas. 
Sunderland Central takes in the centre of the city of Sunderland itself and the coastal village of Ryhope to the South. 
To the north it includes Roker, site of Sunderland AFC`s former stadium, and Monkwearmouth home to the club’s Stadium of Light, and the affluent suburb of Fulwell. 
Sunderland itself is a former shipbuilding and coal mining town, both industries which have all but disappeared. 
Sunderland famously rejected Brexit and even though Tory leader Theresa May has put herself forward as the ‘Brexit candidate’ it’s a huge ask for them to take this seat where, last time out, Julie Elliott who is standing again for Labour had an 11,000 majority. To be taken by the Conservatives, it would require a huge 13.5% swing.
